title: How to Make Fluffy Rice

steps.headline: Pour the rice into a bowl and cover it with cold water.
steps.description: Pick a bowl big enough to hold the rice. Pour water into the bowl, and mix it up with your hands. You can also use a spoon to agitate the water. You should see the water turn cloudy, which is the starch from the rice sloughing off.

steps.headline: Strain the rice through a fine metal sieve.
steps.description: Pour the rice into a sieve over the sink. The sieve just needs to be fine enough to keep the rice from falling out. Let the water drain out the bottom. Alternatively, you can simply rinse the rice under running water in the sieve. You'll need to rinse it for about a minute.

steps.headline: Repeat the process a couple of times until the water runs clear.
steps.description: Put the rice back in the bowl, and add water again. Agitate the water, and then drain the water off in the sieve. Keep going until the water is clear when you agitate it.

steps.headline: Measure the rice, salt, and water.
steps.description: Part of making fluffy rice is getting the ratio of water to rice correct. For every 1 cup (240 mL) of long grain white rice, you'll need 1 ⁄3 to 1 ⁄4 cups (390 to 410 mL) of water. You'll need to experiment with the pan you're using, as the right ratio changes depending on the size of the pan and how much water the lid lets out of the pan. Use less water for a firmer texture. You can use as little as 1 ⁄4 cups (300 mL) of water. Use 1 teaspoon (4.9 mL) of salt for every 1 cup (240 mL) of rice. Short grain white rice needs slightly less water. You might get away with a 1-to-1 ration.

steps.headline: Boil the water first.
steps.description: Pour the water and salt into a pot large enough to hold the water, salt, and rice. Heat the water over high heat on the stove. Watch for it to reach a rolling boil. The water will have bubbles first, then it will lightly boil, moving the surface slightly. A rolling boil is when the surface is bubbling and moving a lot.

steps.headline: Add the rice to the pot and stir.
steps.description: Once the water is boiling, it's time to pour in the rice. Keep the rice as close to the surface of the water as you can when you pour. That way, you won't splash boiling water on yourself. Stir the rice lightly. You just want it to spread out along the bottom of the pot. If you stir too much, the rice will become sticky.

steps.headline: Let the rice come back to a boil and then lower the heat.
steps.description: Watch the rice for 1-2 minutes. It should start to boil lightly again in this time period. The bubbles should form small craters or depressions in the water. Lower the heat to let it simmer. Typically, you want a medium-low heat. That's enough to keep it simmering. You don't want it to burn on the bottom.

steps.headline: Cover and leave the rice to cook for about 20 minutes.
steps.description: Watch the rice to make sure it's not at a rolling boil any more. Once the rice has stopped boiling so much, put the lid on the pot, and leave it alone to cook. Do not try to stir it during this time. Just walk away.

steps.headline: Take the rice off the heat and cover it with a towel.
steps.description: Check to make sure all the water is absorbed, which indicates the rice is done. Rice needs time to rest so the water distributes properly. With the rice off the heat, take the lid off, and put a clean towel across the top of the pot. Put the lid back on over the towel. The towel keeps condensation from dripping into the rice.

steps.headline: Leave the rice alone for 15-20 minutes.
steps.description: Keep the rice off the heat during this time. You just want it to sit. If you're worried about it getting cold, wrap the pot in a towel to keep it warm while resting works its magic.

steps.headline: Fluff the rice with a fork and serve.
steps.description: Open the lid, and use a fork to scoop at the rice, fluffing it. Add in a little butter at this point, if you'd like. Scoop it onto plates or bowls to serve. If you've only made fluffy rice once, taste it before serving. See if it's to you're liking so you can adjust your recipe next time. Put leftovers in an airtight container and keep them in the fridge. Use the rice within 4-6 days, but don't reheat it more than once.
